newsitem.title: GERMANY: Buba's Koebnick - rate cut could not trim jobless.
newsitem.headline: Buba's Koebnick - rate cut could not trim jobless.

text.p: A senior Bundesbank official said on Friday that another interest rate cut could not help bring down Germany's record-high unemployment rate.

Bundesbank council member Hans-Juergen Koebnick said "that would not take any unemployed person off the street" in answer to questions whether another cut in the Bundesbank's main money market rate could help chisel away at high unemployment rates.
Buba's Koebnick - rate cut could not trim jobless
Koebnick, also president of the state central bank in the Rhineland-Palatinate and Saar regions, added "the function of monetary policy at the moment is consistency and stability."
The Bundesbank on Thursday left its three key interest rates, the 2.50 percent discount rate, the 4.50 percent Lombard rate and the three percent repo rate, unchanged.

Koebnick declined to speculate about what will come out of today's meeting between Italian prime minister Romano Prodi and Chancellor Helmut Kohl, or whether Italy would be among the first to join a European currency union in 1999.
"It remains to be seen what comes out today," he said.
Buba's Koebnick - rate cut could not trim jobless

Koebnick last year suggested that southern European nations would likely not be ready to join the currency union at its launch as their efforts to consolidate finances were still at the beginning stages.
